summary.p: [The Bernese pastors] want to oppose the efforts of Theodor [Bibliander]; the moment is unfavorable to undertake anything against Bucer. The letter from the Zurichers [No. 1073] has met with their approval; Megander has passed it on to [Peter Cyro] to possibly bring it to the council. He has heard that the hospital master has moved into his house; he urgently requests to arrange for the temporary accommodation of his household goods. The Bernese are putting their church in danger; he opposes them but exercises restraint.

div.p: We will, as much as we can, thwart Theodor's efforts; certainly, at this time, it seems unwise to attempt anything against Bucer or anyone else.

We have read the letters you sent. Certainly, there is no one among us who does not highly approve of them, unless it befit a good man to praise while standing and to blame while sitting. The letters were delivered by me to the secretaries, and a copy was given to them so that, if it seems appropriate, they may ensure they are read by the council; however, they have not yet been read.

I hear that the hospital master has moved into my house; but I do not understand what has been done with my furniture. I beg you, by the Lord, to arrange for suitable accommodation for me until I can have the one assigned to me.

Our schemers; for they are hastening the ruin of our church by their complaints, indeed by their discovered crime. So that I do not appear contentious, I oppose them only in public sermons, yet with utmost modesty.
To the pious and learned men Bullinger and Leo, the most vigilant ministers and brothers of the Zurich church.
